title: Thursday, 25th July 2019
bodyHTML:
Soundbuy Morning
Blank canvas Good morning all
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Good morning.

BE11:05am

I have just been to see His Majesty Paul Murphy who has invited me to host another Markets Live, FT Alphavile's thing with the typing and etc.

Maverick Good Morning all
BE11:05am

And I begin by paying tribute to the fortitude and patience of you, the ROTR, for putting up with me once more.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

There are pessimists at home and abroad who think that after twelve or so years of typos, waffle and sellside, that Markets Live has run its course.

Blank canvas too hot for me - can we have a short session today?
BE11:06am

But so I am standing before you today to tell you, the ROTR, that the doubters, the doomsters, the gloomsters are wrong.

BE11:06am

To those that say that prophesise disaster, I say: do not underestimate this website. Our powers have overcome technological disasters on a near daily basis.

Maverick See ya later Metro Bank
11:06 am
BE11:06am

To those that say "Any grey on SXX?" I say: "stop talking in stock tickers please we've been over this."

AMALtd morning
BE11:06am

Let us be clear. The people who bet against Markets Live are going to lose their shirts. As are the people betting with it. There will be shirts lost. That much is certain.

BE11:06am

So with high hearts and growing confidence, we will now accelerate towards the stocks portion of the day.

BornCynic Good morning
11:06 am
BE11:07am

The time has come to act, to take decisions, to give strong leadership and to change this blog for the better.

BE11:07am

We pledge to give the ROTR the markets coverage it deserves, and that work begins now.

Boris brings flair, a clear Brexit message, new ideas and appeal across the electorate that no other candidate, however competent and decent, could reach. His primary task over the next few months is to give a positive and resolute lead on Brexit and keep his promise to leave the EU on 31st October, no ifs, no buts, no equivocation – with or without signing an acceptable Withdrawal Agreement. Already, fresh leadership is bringing with it a renewed sense of purpose and belief, hope and optimism, for both MPs and the country. The future is bright.

UBS incoming.

BE11:17am

Cobham four activities which are independent
Cobham portfolio can be easily broken down as it already operates in four entities
Communications and Connectivity, Mission Systems, Advanced Electronics Solutions,
Aviation Services. Advent does not currently own A&D assets but the turn-around
opportunity is significant in our view. Cobham sales are 38% US defence exposed, 26%
UK and RoW defence 36% Commercial.
Interim results released today with a 7% beat on EBIT and much better FCF
Good start to the year, FY expectations remain unchanged, 11% organic growth was
delivered across all the businesses which is impressive. 1H19 EBIT came at £107mn vs
£100mn consensus and FCF was much better £(15)mn outflow vs UBS est of £(55)mn and
cons. at £(80)mn on better working capital management and lower capex on asset sale.
Valuation a 35% premium implies 14.7x EV/EBITA excluding synergies
Cobham on 123p trades on 10.9x 2020E EV/EBITA and 8.1x 2020E EV/EBITDA in our
estimates and a 35% premium (166p implied price) would value the business assuming no
synergies at 14.7x 2020E EV/EBITA and 10.9x 2020E EV/EBITDA. This compares to 11.5x
EV/EBITA for the UK names on 2020E and 13.3x for the defence average

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And Jefferies

BE11:18am

DCF valuation of Cobham is 162p ... That assumed no further losses on the KC-46 Tanker programme and a 15% EBIT average long-term EBIT margin.
Were the margin 14%, our DCF valuation reduced to 153p. In short, we regard the offer from Advent as essentially removing all execution risk, notably in Advanced Electronic Solutions, but also related to the AVIATOR S satcom in Communications & Connectivity. That unquestionably has its attractions, in our view.
Details: We figure a trade buyer might see still more value, but identifying a trade buyer that would not risk alienating customers – notably defence prime contractors - is challenging, in our view. Cobham's 1H19 results show Sales of £1,028.9 (JEFe £908.7m), Adjusted EBIT of £107.1m (JEFe £98m).

BE11:19am

On the flipside, what chance a regulatory block?

nichoman does boris need to flex his national security muscles and block something ? there's inmarsat as well remember
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Clearance needed from the UK, Australia, France and Finland .... though weirdly not the US, where Cobham gets a third of its revenue.

nichoman or maybe just let both through and show britain open for business
OnYourRight Morning all
BE11:21am

Versus a quarter from UK MOD. If we consider the slightly baffling Inmarsat intervention we probably can't write off someone in Whitehall getting pissy about this one.

BE11:21am

Here's Olivetree.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

True to form in the UK, Cobham will trade tight/through the deal terms. In Cobham’s case the amount of the previous bid speculation, lack of irrevocables and sector consolidation creates a more exciting start point vs. some other announced UK transactions at present. The transaction has been put together reasonably quickly behind the scenes. The transaction value is broadly in line with comparable deals however there should be room for a higher price depending on the credibility assigned to Cobham’s margin recovery, potential value creation from a review of the Australian business and any synergy potential for a strategic acquirer.

On the other hand, the UK FDI approval is the (only) stand out regulatory condition. Given the extremely recent change of Government, it would be somewhat premature to take a strong view on the approach to foreign acquisitions of UK assets. Whilst clearly an information submission to the CMA could change this, the market has become quite comfortable that UK government is approaching the national security review of Inmarsat as a matter of prudence as opposed to anything more worrying. This is an imperfect but not a defunct data point given that the review was initiated days prior to the personnel changes in government. Current guidance is for a year-end deal close, a UK government in depth review could take up to 24 weeks – significantly delaying transaction closing. News flow around this review could create opportunities to acquire Cobham at a spread.

K-NUCK because its a us buyer...cfius not needed
Blank canvas Philip Stephens's analysis of Boris is the best i've read so far. "Second rate huckster" etc https://www.ft.com/content/507c6e0e-ae13-11e9-8030-530adfa879c2
BE11:22am

Cobham shareholders will vote on the transaction on September 16th, c7 weeks from now and ahead of Brexit. That said, there is clearly potential for a significant FX move upon a hard Brexit with a meaningful impact on the value of Cobham to a US acquirer or the value of Cobham’s US revenues (52% of group) to a late coming European acquirer – so, like Inmarsat/Ophir, we may again see postulation around the ability of a target to wriggle out of a Scheme post vote.

Here's Goodbody with a point list of what's said.

Ghazali mng all. late entry here.
11:31 am
BE11:31am

1) Overall: MTRO entered loss-making territory in 2Q19. NIM and overall profitability are major challenges for the bank and will replace capital as the key talking points for the rest of the year.
2) Deposits shrunk by 9.2% q/q in 2Q19 and have declined by 12.5% since end-FY18. While this is very concerning, management noted that there were greater than £700m of net inflows in June and July MTD. We believe that MTRO can grow its deposit book again (h/h) in 2H19 though commercial outflows appear to be continuing and management guidance looks stretched.
3) Net loans flat q/q – and will shrink in 2H19 due to asset sales but we should see some organic growth in originations again though mortgages bias is a real issue.
4) Further NIM shrinkage to less than 1.60% for 2Q19 with negative guidance for 2H19 owing to higher deposit costs, MREL, loan sale, and asset mix shift.

BE11:31am

5) Strong uplift in fee income (impressive), high opex in 2Q19 but growth set to moderate (consistent with previous guidance), and minimal CoR of just 6bps.
6) Strong CET1 capital ratio owing to capital raise and asset sale (+30bps) and sufficient at 16.1%. £521m loan sales didn’t relate to assets that were the subject of RWA misstatements. Signposting and we expect more sales in 2H19.
7) LCR +24pps to 163% explained by lower deposit funding requirements (equity raise), sale of non-HQLA assets, better quality deposits (term vs. demand) – and, we suspect, a change in composition of pre-existing HQLA assets. CFO said sale of loan portfolio was to drive down LTD, which doesn’t appear to stack up – but we suspect it was done: i) to demonstrate evidence of ability to sell assets for a good price; and ii) due to intended future liquid assets rebalancing.

BE11:32am

They're still not keen.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

While medium-term guidance was reaffirmed and opex savings guidance was upgraded marginally it is hard to attach any credibility to the FY23 low double-digit RoE target given NIM challenges and cost structure. We continue to believe there is a material divergence between market value and intrinsic value and we continue to rate MTRO a SELL. TP of 367p UNDER REVIEW with material downside risk. We believe that the optimal ‘end game’ is for MTRO to be sold to a third party.

madrugada BE, I see you are inspired by our new PM. Keep the enthusiasm up.
Ghazali Can anyone point me to who the best sellsider is on UK listed RE companies / housebuilders etc. ? or at least who wrote the best recent sector primerpls

BE11:33am

And Exane.

BE11:33am

The P&L was almost a third wheel at Q2 results for Metro. This quarter was all about the
movement in deposits following the outflows seen in Q1. And on this metric we were concerned to
see Metro miss expectations as the rate of deposit outflows accelerated to GBP1.4bn in Q2. There
were a few green-shoots with Metro seeing GBP0.7bn of inflows in June/July, giving support to its
new guidance for FY19 deposits to be flat YoY. But the prospect of a Hard Brexit is a real concern
for deposit growth, especially considering that the recent consecutive quarters of deposit outflows
occurred in non-stressed market conditions.

YourGrannyOnBongos Not sure now is an optimal time for banking consolidation...
TrustMyUnit The Tesco rights issue saga was ML ;)
11:34 am
BE11:34am

The volatility of deposit flows underscores the view put forward in our recent initiaton of the
elevated liquidity position Metro will need to hold, especially with an eye towards repaying
GBP3.8bn of TFS debt over 2020/22. The announcement of the resale of a GBP521m loan
portfolio back to Cerberus (with portfolio economics unchanged from when Metro originally
acquired it) appears primarily motivated by the need to raise liquidity, and a similar rationale seems
behind the sale of GBP1.5bn of treasury assets in Q2. Further portfolio sales seem highly likely on
the current trajectory. However, the repercussion of holding such higher liquidity is the sacrifice of
higher margin growth, explain our 40% below consensus net income forecasts for 2020e (pre-Q2).

BE11:34am

Outside of deposit flows, the quarter was characterised by a 4% NII miss as NIM fell to 1.61%, fees
GBP1m ahead (ex asset sales), and a 1% miss on costs, giving a 33% miss at PPP. Impairments
remained benign at just 6bp. CET1 comfortable at 15.8% following the recent equity raise.

FATDAZ Re Metro bank the weaknesses that I feared would emerge seem to be coming to the fore changing the management is a positive assuming there are no more horrors but rebuilding the business and reputation will be harder my guess is it's bought out at little or no premium in the next 12 to 18 months tops
BE11:35am

We cut estimates to reflect the earlier than anticipated portfolio sale and implications for near-term
profitability on a low profit base. Trading at a premium (0.5x TNAV) to its returns outlook (4%
2022e ROE), with elevated CoE risk due to regulatory investigations, we reiterate Underperform.

Ghazali @Maverick, not sure what Amazon gains from ASOS ? they are already larger in the UK, and have better logistics in both UK & US.
11:35 am

marktime There are several UK listed companies trading at 10-20% below book value, ideal bid candidates at these exchange rates, more to come surely
BE11:36am

While there is clearly light at the end of the tunnel for Metro (deposit growth has inflected, capital levels are healthy, corporate governance has improved dramatically, and targeted expense savings are being increased), the bank still has some near-term challenges, in our view, which could keep the shares range bound. More specifically, raising MREL debt, improving NIM, and navigating the regulatory landscape all remain challenges that leave us maintaining our Market Perform rating. While the shares are unquestionably cheap at about 0.5x TBV (versus large cap UK peers at about 0.8x and small-cap peers at 1.2x), Metro's lack of profitability relative to its peers is notable, with a clearer path towards improvement likely needed.

In a previous life I was a tech reporter. Sage results were the dullest to cover. Always in line, always dull as anything. Shrink wrapped software reliably renewed on an annual basis by the world's most predictable people, accountants.

Grouchmonkey burford is just up on their figures, isn't it? Very good figures they are too (disclosure - I have some)
BE11:44am

Sage has reported fiscal Q3’19 organic total revenue growth of 5.3% and 5.9% for the first 9 months (no
consensus for Q3 but FY19 consensus is 6.1%). Recurring revenue increased by 11.4%, helped by strong growth
in software subscriptions (reflecting continued focus on attracting new customers and migrating existing
customers to subscription and the cloud). In addition, recurring revenue growth has been helped by a weaker
comp and strength in the UKI as new regulations on digital tax submissions attract new and existing customers
to the latest version of software. The company has updated its guidance – stating that FY19 recurring revenue
growth is to slightly exceed guidance of 8-9%, and the combined decline in SSRS and processing revenue to be
slightly greater than the decline seen in the first 9months (13% decline). The company has also stated the
organic operating profit margin is expected to be at the lower end of the guided range of 23-25% (consensus
24.3%). Assuming 10% recurring revenue growth and -15% declines in SSRS and Processing, as well as a 23%
operating profit margin, this implies a ~6% cut to consensus expectations for FY19 operating profit. In
summary, Sage has experienced a large re-rating YTD, despite consensus earnings estimates actually
coming down for EPS, and now trades on 27x/25x 2019/2020 P/E (consensus estimates), which is a
premium to respective peers despite lower margins and lower topline growth. In addition, Sage’s current
trading multiple is the highest it has ever been. In light of the weaker performance today, the potential
downgrades and the significant re-rating experienced YTD, we would expect notable share price
weakness,

11:44 am
BE11:45am

That's Caz.

software sector on 24.3x and 16.7x

Bluesky21 Intuit is on 45x P/E
BE11:46am

While the accelerated shift to recurring revenue as highlighted in Sage’s 3QFY19 trading update is a positive, lowered FY19 margin guidance is likely to weigh on the stock, in our view, given the recent share price outperformance.
3QFY19 organic revenue growth of 5.3% was below our expectations (GSe for 3QFY19 organic revenue growth of c.6.7%), albeit driven by a higher than expected decline in the lower quality SSRS business. We note that the growth of the high quality recurring revenue came in broadly in line with our expectations at 11.4% yoy in 3QFY19 (vs. GSe: 11.2%), with software subscription organic growth in line to better than our expectations (3QFY19 growth of 28.3% vs GSe of 27%).
On the other hand, the company lowered the operating margin guidance for FY19 towards the lower end of the earlier guided range of 23-25%. While Sage also communicated that it now expects recurring revenue to grow slightly above the 8%-9% range, we note that the street is already at c.10% growth for recurring revenue. All in, we expect the near term street estimates to come down modestly, given the lowered operating margin guidance.

Tom Dalgleish That could better be put in a table of numbers
Tom Dalgleish It mixes qualitative with quantitative in a narrative which breaks reader focus

red sage may need to wash out to around 650 but should be ok. once the numbers start coming thru it will be in the sp, so its one of these if u believe they can execute the move to cloud, then the sp may behave a bit like adobe did thru that time.
BE11:47am

............... o ...... kay ......?

BE11:47am

Q3 Update report has ‘puts and takes’. Sage guides for recurring revenue growth to slightly exceed
guidance of 8-9% with the combined decline in SSRS and processing revenue to be slightly greater,
organic operating profit margin to be at the lower end of the guided range of 23-25%." To reflect the
news, we reduce revenue and profit (see below). Yes the ride is bumpy, but North America and UKI
remain positive and we had flagged our concerns on Enterprise products and the new office move
previously. Sage’s ambition – to be a great SaaS company – is thus far unfulfilled but the building
blocks are there. We note: (i) Intacct's arrival is well known by all (recap there will be a soft launch in
Australia this summer – no sign of it there yet) and so this may lead to a 'stall effect' in customer in
FYQ4 sales (we think it is a reason for some caution by Sage), (ii) competitors also know that Intacct
is coming and so are likely to push aggressively on competitive sales campaigns in the coming six
months, (iii) in the UK, 'Brexit' is creating an uncertain climate for business investment, time and
again ‘uncertainty’ is a byword for delayed business, and (iv) street corner research suggests a
slower Enterprise market. Forecast changes prompt a reduction to our target price to 771p (prior
781p). As the Blues Brothers would say, Sage is “on a mission from God.”

VV75 are you saying they are on a mission from God?
Excel Developer #ECB today, tee up more stimulus or pull the trigger on more stimulus?
Sails Coo, Cobham. They have a fleet of (at least) 4 identical noisy jets that take off from Bournemouth airport and test missile attachments, avionics and, allegedly, go spotting for migrants crossing the Channel in a rib.

Tom Dalgleish But its entertaining

red @Excel Developereuro will be near 113 today if they dont do anything. they need to tee up and then draghi needs to be ultra dovish to keep euro from staying abv 112 when it bounces on no change. even if they cut 10bps its half priced in. bar is high today, they need to do a lot and say a lot afterwards.
BE11:49am

We expect the market to be taken somewhat by surprise by Sage’s 3Q19 quarter. Headline growth has remained soft at 5.3%, albeit again with strength in recurring (+11.4% versus 10.2% for H1 despite a tougher comp) and further weakness in SSRS (down ~23%, worse than Q2) with Sage calling out weakness in X3. The revenue guidance changes suggest a tough Q4. More unexpected though is guidance that Sage will be at the low end of the FY margin range. Costs were not being put that quickly into the business during H1 and H1 profitability was ahead of expectations, so this implies a sharp y/y reduction in H2 (greater than 600bp). We question what implication this has for run-rate profitability into the following year.

Our view on the shares is based on Burford being a leader in a market that has
many avenues for growth which has driven significant developments in the
group’s balance sheet investment portfolio and ongoing commitments in
response to greater demand for its services (see here). We see future
opportunities as Burford increases its presence in global markets including in its
largest market, the US (which Burford believes is still underserved) as well as
internationally (c.49% of balance sheet commitments in FY18 were outside North

BE11:59am

Record revenues (+40% yoy) and profits (+37%): In the six months to June,
Burford generated $287m of income (92% from the balance sheet litigation
finance business) and $225m of post-tax profit, an impressive 78% margin.
This meant that the annualised return on equity remained high at 31%
(FY18: 30%). Burford now has $2.8bn of current investments (defined as
invested capital plus undrawn commitments) across three capital sources
(balance sheet, funds and the arrangement with the sovereign wealth fund
(SWF)). Operationally, Burford has been busy in the period: it committed
$130m in a new form of portfolio financing that has taken more than a year
to complete but positions Burford as a long-term financing solution for the
counterparty; similarly it added two new “innovative” investments in asset
recovery; it also closed a new $300m post settlement fund; and lastly it
sold a further 10% of its Petersen interests for $1bn.
● Commitments up by 36% yoy; an all-time high: In total, Burford entered
new commitments of $751m in H1, up by 36% yoy (although up only 4%
sequentially as there is some seasonality). Of this, the balance sheet
(including asset recovery) contributed $363m (48%), funds $276m (37%)
and the SWF $112m (15%). The mix of business stayed relatively consistent;
portfolio finance and complex/recourse deals made up the majority at 65%
(H218: 64%). On the balance sheet litigation finance business, although
deployments (ie investments/cash outflows) were lower, at $129m (H218:
$395m), this was somewhat affected by the deployments being made by the
SWF and timing. Recoveries (gross cash received/inflows) were strong, at
$301m (H218: $206m), or 20% of the opening portfolio.
● Petersen continues to boost returns: Burford generated $265m (+36% yoy)
of total portfolio income, of which 51% was net fair value movements. This
is a large improvement on H218, in which the proportion was 81%. Returns
on concluded investments, which partially includes Petersen, both ROIC
and IRR jumped to 98% and 32% respectively. Both results were affected by
activity in the Petersen case. In our preview, we estimated that Petersen
would contribute c$121m to income, comprising $98.2m of net realised
gains, and $23m of net fair value movements. This implies 46% of the total
$265m came from Petersen.
● Strong liquidity position, indebtedness stays low: Burford ended the
period with a strong liquidity position, holding $171m of cash and
equivalents, improved further in July by the receipt of a further $126m,
bringing the pro-forma total to c$297m. This compares to $773m of
undrawn commitments, of which c50% are expected to be drawn in the
next 12 months. The balance sheet maintained relatively low leverage, with
net debt/equity of 30% (FY18: 27%).

Headline metrics appear strong but on a cash basis progress appears to be slower. We remain
of the view that BUR will require external fundraising in H2 if it is to achieve our balance sheet
lending expectation. Total income, $287m, +40% y/y. Litigation investment income contributed
$265m, +36% y/y. Of this, net realised gains (i.e. cash) were $124.7m, +3% y/y (includes
$100m from the Petersen secondary sale completed in June). Fair value movements were
$134.7m, +80% y/y and 47% of total income. Balance sheet additions were down by 41%
y/y. Cash and cash equivalents have declined to $127.6m (including the $100m from the
Petersen sale). This compares to $237.5m at the end of 2018 and $236.0m at the end of
H1’18. Unless BUR is able to raise external sources of funding, our current forecast for onbalance
sheet additions of $742.8m for the full year ($657.7m in FY18) appears to be a stretch
too far ($147.2m deployed ytd). Stock trades on forecast FY19 cash NAV of 5.1x CY19 falling to
4.2x CY20 for a forecast 23% cash ROE through our forecast period. Maintain SELL.

BE12:06pm

Today’s profit warning is merely confirmation that Aston Martin Lagonda, like
all carmakers, is essentially a cyclical business with limited visibility and high
operational gearing. Hence, the need for a strong balance sheet if one is trying
to move away from the pack and become like Ferrari. What should worry
investors most about today’s update is not that volumes are likely to be 11%
below expectations but that the management is cutting capex. While the CEO is
still backing the Second Century Plan, the pressure to keep net debt under
control raises the risk that it may be curtailed or even abandoned. We believe
the only way to get back on track is to raise fresh equity of at least c£1bn. We
expect the shares to remain under pressure until the capital structure is aligned
with the long-term growth strategy. At this stage, we must assume no change in
the capital structure, and based on our revised forecasts our DCF model now
values the shares at 543p (802p). We maintain our SELL recommendation.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Q2 has delivered the quarter we anticipated and more ... with not only a beat despite weak externalization but a guidance raise in addition: Q2 is a 5% sales beat (+6% vs BARC) driven by a 5% product sales beat with most importantly beats for all three of the key launch assets Imfinzi, Tagrisso and Lynparza (+3/13/8% ahead of consensus respectively). Despite both externalization and other operating income missing vs consensus by 11/24% respectively, core EBITA for Q2 came in 17% ahead of consensus (although only +2% vs BARC…) driven by operating leverage with absolute SG&A/R&D in-line and COGS slightly better. Financials were a miss as was tax, but that nonetheless delivered a 19% beat vs company consensus core EPS (in-line with BARC on core EPS so we can’t quite explain how consensus arrived at that math of a better core EPS beat vs EBITA despite the tax/financials miss…). Guidance is lifted for product sales to low DD vs prior HSD with core EBITA growth of mid-teens and core EPS of $3.50-.70 both reiterated; FX is maintained at a LSD headwind. That upgraded guidance is ahead of both BARC/consensus, which currently model reported FY19 product sales +9/8% respectively, with core EBITA +11/13% and core EPS of $3.49/3.52 respectively. Cashflow is also a marked improvement on Q1 with weak but acceptable H1 CFO figure of $0.5bn reversing both the outflow seen at Q1 and in H1’18. Overall this looks about as good a set of results as we could have hoped and with Q2 CC product sales accelerating to +19% (+17% for H1) even the upgraded guidance (which is ahead of us) looks conservative.
